-e (quantity of the first dimension in the dative)

etymology_text:
From Middle English by, bi, from Old English bī (“by; near; around”), from Proto-West Germanic *bī, from Proto-Germanic *bi (“near; by; around; about”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁epi.
Cognate with West Frisian by (“by; near”), Afrikaans by (“at; by; near”), Saterland Frisian bie (“near; by”), Dutch bij (“near; by”), German Low German bi (“by; near; at”), German bei (“by; near; at”).

etymology_templates.name: cog
etymology_templates.expansion: German Low German bi (“by; near; at”)

synonyms.english: archaic for preposition and adverb, not used for abbreviation, preferred for noun and interjection

examples.text: You should brush your teeth twice a day.
I've done with my tirade. The world was gone; / The twice two thousand, for whom earth was made, / Were vanish'd to be what they call alone
examples.ref: 1824, Lord Byron, “Canto the Thirteenth”, in Don Juan:

examples.text: He could not be induced to remain permanently at Mohair because Miss Trevor was at Asquith, but he appropriated a Hempstead cart from the Mohair stables and made the trip sometimes twice in a day.

glosses: Two times.

examples.text: Thus it appears that if the machine is turning twice as slow as before, there is more than twice the former quantity in the rising buckets; and more will be raised in a minute by the same expenditure of power.

examples.text: MARY: As you go from left to right, each example has twice as many twos; from right to left, twice as few.

examples.text: Both men and women with higher qualifications were twice as less likely to be unemployed than their less qualified counterparts.

etymology_text: From earlier twise, from Middle English twies, twiȝes, from Old English twīġes (“twice”), from twīwa, twīġa ("twice"; whence Middle English twie (“twice”)) + -es (adverbial genitive ending). Related to Saterland Frisian twäie (“twice”), Middle Low German twiges, twies (“twice”), Middle High German zwies (“twice”). Compare also twi- meaning two or both.

args.1: "twice"; whence Middle English twie (“twice”)

A (usually) metal fastener consisting of a partially or completely threaded shank, sometimes with a threaded point, and a head used to both hold the top material and to drive the screw either directly into a soft material or into a prepared hole.

examples.text: The screws moved her out of my cell because they could not stand the idea of a black and white white being together.

examples.text: And that's how it came to pass that on the second-to-last day of the job, the convict crew that tarred the plate factory roof in the spring of forty-nine wound up sitting in a row at ten o'clock in the morning drinking icy cold, Bohemia-style beer, courtesy of the hardest screw that ever walked a turn at Shawshank State Prison.

examples.text: They both wedged up in his cell and refused to come out. They were hurling abuse at the screws on the other side of the door. As a result they were both shipped out to another jail the following day.

examples.text: A few couples would let selected doggers join in, with the lucky ones managing to get a screw.

examples.text: As she sucked the nicotine deeply into her lungs, she closed her eyes and leaned back against the headboard, enjoying the pleasurable buzz that the combination of a good screw—well, a decent screw—coupled with the nicotine gave.

examples.text: She was just a girl, like any of the girls he had had so easily, just another screw.
examples.ref: 1993, William Gill, Fortune's Child, HarperCollins Canada, published 1994, →ISBN, page 42:

examples.text: Mary was Eli's favorite screw because she was clean, pretty, a good mother, funny, and alway was able to make herself available for their twice a week fucks as easily as he was.

derived.word: the first turn of the screw pays all debts

etymology_text:
From Middle English screw, scrue (“screw”); apparently, despite the difference in meaning, from Old French escroue (“nut, cylindrical socket, screwhole”), from Latin scrōfa (“female pig”) through comparison with the corkscrew shape of a pig's penis. There is also the Old French escruve (“screw”), from Old Dutch *scrūva ("screw"; whence Middle Dutch schruyve (“screw”)), which probably influenced or conflated with the aforementioned, resulting in the Middle English word.
more on the etymology of screw
Old French escroue (whence Medieval Latin scrofa (“nut, screwhole”)), is believed to be an adaptation of Latin scrōfa (“sow, female pig”); but this development is not found in other Romance languages. (For change in meaning, compare also Spanish puerca, Portuguese porca, both ‘sow; screw nut’, and is based on the fact that a boar's penis has a screw-like tip, making the sow's vulva equivalent to a screw nut by analogy).
Old Dutch *scrūva possibly derives from Proto-Germanic *skrūbō (“screw”), from *skru- (“to cut”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)keru-, *(s)ker- (“to cut”), and is related to German Schraube (“screw”), Low German schruve, schruwe (“screw”), Dutch schroef (“screw”), West Frisian skroef (“screw”), Danish skrue (“screw”), Swedish skruv (“screw, peg”), Icelandic skrúfa (“screw”).
Compare also Occitan escrofa (“screw nut”), Calabrese scrufina (“screw nut”), which may be borrowings of the Old French word, or parallel developments.

etymology_templates.name: der
etymology_templates.expansion: Old French escroue (“nut, cylindrical socket, screwhole”)

args.1: "screw"; whence Middle Dutch schruyve (“screw”)

etymology_text: From Italian torso, from Late Latin tursus, from Latin thyrsus, from Ancient Greek θύρσος (thúrsos, “Bacchic staff”). Doublet of thyrse and thyrsus.

examples.text: She stayed till the very end.
I have to work till eight o'clock tonight.
Similar sentiments will recur to everyone familiar with his writings all through them till the very end.
examples.ref: 1854, Prof. John Wilson, The Genius and Character of Burns, page 194:

examples.text: The line was authorised on June 23, 1864, but not opened till July 11, 1881.
examples.ref: 1946 May and June, G. A. Sekon, “L.B.S.C.R. West Coast Section—3”, in Railway Magazine, page 148:

examples.text: While the PA has not always seen eye-to-eye with US foreign policy, its survival remained, till recently, a top American priority.
examples.ref: 2019 March 14, Ramzy Baroud, “Chasing mirages: What are Palestinians doing to combat ‘Deal of the Century’?”, in Ma'an News, archived from the original on 2019-03-30:

glosses: Until; to, up to; as late as (a given time).

examples.text: It's twenty till two. (1:40)
Is that the town-clock striking? / I think that it is to-night / My fever will reach its crisis, / There are long hours yet till light.
examples.ref: 1880, A. T. Fullerton, “Fever”, in Littell's Living Age, volume 147, page 578:

glosses: Before (a certain time or event).

examples.text: They led him till his tent
She, poor bird, as all forlorn / Lean'd her breast up-till a thorn / And there sung the dolefull'st ditty, / To to hear it was great pity.
examples.ref: 1599, William Shakespeare (attributed), The Passionate Pilgrim:

examples.text: And till the kirk she wadna gae, / nor till't she wadna ride, / Till four-and-twenty men she gat her before, / And twenty on ilka side
examples.ref: 1806, “Lord Wa'Yates and Auld Ingram”, in Robert Jameson, editor, Popular Ballads and Songs, volume 2:

examples.text: For a king to gang an outlaw till / Is beneath his state and his dignitie.
examples.ref: 1838, “The Outlaw Murray”, in Walter Scott, editor, Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border:

glosses: To, up to (physically).

examples.text:
"Here's at you old hoss!" hiccupped I, with a friendly pitch in the way of a nod at Rice.
"Go it, young grampus, that's me! Here's till ye, my infant progidy!" replied he, as he clinked his glass against mine.
examples.ref: 1861, E. J. Guerin, Mountain Charley, page 20:

examples.text: And then she changed her voice and would be as saft as honey: 'My puir wee Ailie, was I thrawn till ye? Never mind, my bonnie. You and me are a' that's left, and we maunna be ill to ither.'
examples.ref: 1902, John Buchan, The Outgoing of the Tide:

VLADIMIR: Together again at last! We'll have to celebrate this. But how? (He reflects.) Get up till I embrace you.

etymology_text: From Middle English til, from Northern Old English til, from or akin to Old Norse til (“to, till”); both from Proto-Germanic *til (“to, toward”), from Proto-Germanic *tilą (“planned point in time”). Not a shortening of until; rather, until comes from till with the prefix un- (“against; toward; up to”) also found in unto. Cognate with Old Frisian til (“to, till”), Danish til (“to”), Swedish till (“to, till”), Icelandic til (“to, till”). Also related to Old English til (“good”), German Ziel (“goal”), Gothic 𐍄𐌹𐌻 (til, “something fitting or suitable”).

examples.text: Maybe you can, maybe you can't: you won't know till you try.
I charge you, O ye daughters of Ierusalem, by the Roes, and by the hindes of the field, that ye stirre not vp, nor awake my loue, till she please.
examples.ref: 1611, The Holy Bible, […] (King James Version), London: […] Robert Barker, […], →OCLC, Song of Solomon 2:7:

examples.text: She twirled round and round, / Till she sunk underground, […]
examples.ref: 1846, Edward Lear, The Book of Nonsense:

examples.text: And the Mouse sat and laughed till he cried.
examples.ref: 1912, anonymous, Punky Dunk and the Mouse, P.F. Volland & Co.

glosses: Until, until the time that.

etymology_text: From Middle English til, from Northern Old English til, from or akin to Old Norse til (“to, till”); both from Proto-Germanic *til (“to, toward”), from Proto-Germanic *tilą (“planned point in time”). Not a shortening of until; rather, until comes from till with the prefix un- (“against; toward; up to”) also found in unto. Cognate with Old Frisian til (“to, till”), Danish til (“to”), Swedish till (“to, till”), Icelandic til (“to, till”). Also related to Old English til (“good”), German Ziel (“goal”), Gothic 𐍄𐌹𐌻 (til, “something fitting or suitable”).

examples.text: If you can wait until after my meeting with her, we'll talk then.

Seeing the British establishment struggle with the financial sector is like watching an alcoholic […]. Until 2008 there was denial over what finance had become. When a series of bank failures made this impossible, there was widespread anger, leading to the public humiliation of symbolic figures.
examples.ref: 2013 June 28, Joris Luyendijk, “Our banks are out of control”, in The Guardian Weekly, volume 189, number 3, page 21:

glosses: Up to the time of (something happening).

examples.text: Keep walking until the second set of traffic lights, then turn left.

glosses: Up to (a certain place)

examples.text: I was about to say that I had known the Celebrity from the time he wore kilts. But I see I will have to amend that, because he was not a celebrity then, nor, indeed, did he achieve fame until some time after I left New York for the West.

etymology_text: From Middle English vntil, until, untill, ontil, ontill, equivalent to un- (“against; toward; up to”) + till. Perhaps representing a northern variant of Middle English unto. See unto.

examples.text: It was April 22, 1831, and a young man was walking down Whitehall in the direction of Parliament Street.[…]. He halted opposite the Privy Gardens, and, with his face turned skywards, listened until the sound of the Tower guns smote again on the ear and dispelled his doubts.
examples.ref: 1906, Stanley J[ohn] Weyman, chapter I, in Chippinge Borough, New York, N.Y.: McClure, Phillips & Co., →OCLC, page 01:

examples.text: Imagine a country where children do nothing but play until they start compulsory schooling at age seven. Then, without exception, they attend comprehensives until the age of 16. Charging school fees is illegal, and so is sorting pupils into ability groups by streaming or setting.
examples.ref: 2013 July 19, Peter Wilby, “Finland spreads word on schools”, in The Guardian Weekly, volume 189, number 6, page 30:

glosses: Up to the time that (a condition becomes true).

examples.text: It is never possible to settle down to the ordinary routine of life at sea until the screw begins to revolve. There is an hour or two, after the passengers have embarked, which is disquieting and fussy.
examples.ref: 1915, G[eorge] A. Birmingham [pseudonym; James Owen Hannay], chapter I, in Gossamer, New York, N.Y.: George H. Doran Company, →OCLC:

glosses: Before (a condition becoming true).

etymology_text: From Middle English vntil, until, untill, ontil, ontill, equivalent to un- (“against; toward; up to”) + till. Perhaps representing a northern variant of Middle English unto. See unto.

examples.text: Many people in Texas and New Mexico live in adobe houses.
“Find me a nice, clean adobe wall,” says he, “and send Senor Rompiro up against it.”
examples.ref: 1903, O’Henry, Roads of Destiny:

examples.text: Stone sidewalks, little more than a ledge in width, ran along the base of the mean and monotonous adobe houses.
examples.ref: 1904 November, O. Henry [pseudonym; William Sydney Porter], Cabbages and Kings, New York, N.Y.: McClure, Phillips & Co., page 24:

examples.text: The Jawas mutter gibberish as they busily line up their battered captives, including Artoo and Threepio, in front of the enormous Sandcrawler, which is parked beside a small homestead consisting of three large holes in the ground surrounded by several tall moisture vaporators and one small adobe block house.
examples.ref: 1977, George Lucas, Star Wars (script)

examples.text:
26 May 2003, Roger Angell, in The New Yorker,
The Sangre de Cristos came into view and the first soft-cornered adobe houses, and that night we ate at La Fonda with my Aunt Elsie, who worked for the Indian Bureau, and had Hopi snake dances and San Ildefonso pottery-makers and Mabel Dodge Luhan in store for us in the coming weeks.

examples.text: To play an encore.
